Description: Circular sieve formed from woven palm, with a raised edge.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Amarna, el-, TA:21/301 Workmen's Village, Gate Street, House 12, Kitchen. Other objects found in this room included fragments of similar sieves and baskets, an amphora base, two spools, a clay figurine, a wooden comb, a figured ostraca and a mud-sealing with the cartouche of Tuthmosis III
Curator's comments: Published: Peet and Woolley, City of Akhenaten I (London 1923), 74 pl.22 [fig.2]. Wilson, Egyptian Food and Drink, 1988, p.12. For an unprovenanced sieve of similar form, but with handles and somewhat larger, see Egypt’s Golden Age (exhibition catalogue, Boston, 1982): 138 [no.135]. Such sieves could have been used for sieving a range of dry agricultural products, including for the removal of fine chaff from grain during processing
